plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub native to eastern and southern Asia, Camellia japonica produces large, rose-like flowers that bloom in winter and early spring. Its glossy leaves and vibrant flowers brighten gardens when most plants are dormant.
plants.location: East Asia, cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica flowers have inspired traditional Japanese art and symbolism of love and admiration.

plants.name: Winter Daphne (Daphne odora)
plants.description: A fragrant shrub native to China and Japan, Winter Daphne blooms in late winter with clusters of pink to white tubular flowers that emit a strong, sweet fragrance, attracting pollinators despite the cold.
plants.location: East Asia and temperate gardens globally
plants.funFact: Winter Daphne‚Äôs fragrance is so strong it can be detected from several meters away on a still, cold day.

plants.name: Banksia ericifolia
plants.description: A shrub native to the coastal regions of southeastern Australia, Banksia ericifolia features striking bright orange flower spikes that bloom in the Australian summer, including January, providing important nectar for wildlife.
plants.funFact: Banksia flower spikes are made up of hundreds of tiny flowers tightly packed together, creating a distinctive brush-like appearance.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: An evergreen herbaceous perennial native to alpine regions of Europe, the Christmas Rose blooms in late winter, often flowering through snow, with white to pale pink cup-shaped flowers that add cheer to cold gardens.
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Christmas Rose is not a true rose and is toxic if ingested.
